docs.lead_paragraph: Cigna, the insurance company, said yesterday that it was slashing its third-quarter earnings estimates, reflecting failure to set appropriate prices for the risk it took on in its health plan accounts. Cigna now expects to earn about $205 million before more than $1 billion in previously announced charges, or $1.47 a share. As recently as Sept. 3, Cigna predicted it would earn $1.90 to $2.05 a share. It has taken more than $1 billion in charges against third-quarter earnings on losses from its reinsurance operations, a business it began to exit two years ago. Cigna, which insures about 14 million people, said it would take cost-saving measures that would lead to a charge in the fourth quarter.

headline.main: CIGNA CUTS ITS PROFIT FORECAST FOR THIRD QUARTER

docs.abstract: Cigna is slashing its third-quarter earnings estimates, reflecting failure to set appropriate prices for risk it took on its health plan accounts (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: On a Bronx sidewalk bustling with Saturday shoppers, the federal government persuaded Alma Amill to have a mammogram. Ms. Amill felt a lump in her right breast a few months earlier but had no insurance to pay for the test. Then, in April 1999, someone handed her a leaflet about free breast X-rays, at government expense. So she went right upstairs, to the clinic on the third floor.

headline.main: Mammogram Clinic's Flaws Highlight Gaps in U.S. Rules

docs.abstract: Third article in occasional series, Blurred Vision, focuses on problems that still suffuse practice of mammography in government-sponsored clinics 10 years after Congress stepped in to clean it up; despite unprecedented foray into medical regulation, many clinics still produce poor-quality images; many radiologists lack ability to find breast cancer in shadows of X-ray film; relatively few women are reaping full benefit of mammogram--weapon that experts now realize can save lives only if used well; growing number of experts raise concerns about misread mammograms; Sen Barbara A Mikulski, chief architect of mammography program, says she will push for tougher rules for doctors, such as regular skill tests; case of Dr Steven J Bier of Bronx presented as disaster of government's own making; having signed him up to run clinic for poor women, he and his clinic were held to only minimum standards; later investigation found radiologist who read X-rays missed as many as 25 tumors while spotting only 7; there is no system for monitoring doctors, and Bier case was revealed only by accident; photos; other problems detailed; photos (L)

byline.original: By MICHAEL MOSS with JENNIFER STEINHAUER

docs.lead_paragraph: In May, when Douglas R. Forrester first asserted that his prescription drug insurance company was worth more than $100 million, New Jersey's Republican primary for the Senate quickly changed from a competitive race into a victory lap for Mr. Forrester. But since Mr. Forrester's reported wealth -- and presumed ability to help pay for his Senate race -- turned him from an unknown to the Republican candidate, the $100 million estimate has played a very different role. Now, it appears that the company, of which Mr. Forrester owns 51 percent, is worth far less than $100 million and the original estimate seems to be hindering his campaign, not helping it.

headline.main: Forrester's Estimate of Wealth Seems to Be Hurting, Not Helping

docs.abstract: Douglas Forrester, whose reported wealth of more than $100 million turned him into New Jersey's Republican Senate nominee, finds many Republicans sitting on their checkbooks; he has raised barely $1 million amid revelations that his prescription drug insurance company is worth far less than $100 million; Democrats meanwhile are using claim to accuse him of gouging customers in little-understood field of pharmacy benefit management, companies behind plastic cards that many Americans use to fill prescriptions; his photo (M)
docs.snippet: In May, when Douglas R. Forrester first asserted that his prescription drug insurance company was worth more than $100 million, New Jersey's Republican primary for the Senate quickly changed from a competitive race into a victory lap for Mr....

docs.lead_paragraph: A union that represents nearly 11,000 janitors in the Boston region ended a three-week strike yesterday when it reached a tentative five-year contract that provides 30 percent salary increases and health insurance for some part-time janitors. The labor officials, from Local 254 of the Service Employees International Union, hailed the agreement, saying it was hard to persuade the cleaning companies to grant health coverage to any part-time workers.

headline.main: Tentative Agreement Ends Boston Janitors' Strike

docs.abstract: Service Employees International Union local that represents nearly 11,000 Boston-area janitors reaches tentative five-year contract accord with cleaning companies that ends strike against 97 buildings; pact provides 30 percent salary increases and health insurance for some part-time janitor (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Two major drug companies said yesterday that they would return to the original, deeper discounts that they had been offering to low-income elderly people after they received a letter from the Bush administration stating that the government would not try to demand similar low prices. On Oct. 1, the two companies, GlaxoSmithKline and Bristol-Myers Squibb, cut back on discounts that they had promised to low-income people after becoming concerned that federal officials would demand the same discounts for the government's Medicaid program, which provides health care for the poor.

headline.main: 2 Drug Giants To Restore Big Discounts For Elderly

docs.abstract: GlaxoSmithKline and Bristol-Myers Squibb will return to original, deeper drug discounts that they had been offering to low-income elderly people after receiving letter from Bush administration stating government would not try to demand similar prices; two companies on Oct 1 cut back on discounts they had promised to low-income people afer becoming concerned that federal officials would demand same discounts for government's Medicaid program; drug makers must offer Medicaid lowest price available to any buyer under federal law (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Aetna, seeking to stem rising prescription drug costs, said yesterday that it would end its mail-order contract with a pharmaceutical benefits manager, Express Scripts, and conduct the business itself. Aetna's prescription drug business totals about $4 billion a year, a spokesman said. Aetna, based in Hartford, Conn., will phase out its business with Express Scripts by the second quarter of next year. Express Scripts is based in St. Louis. Aetna also reported its third-quarter results yesterday and said it earned $53 million, up from $32 million a year earlier.

headline.main: AETNA TO BEGIN ACTING AS ITS OWN DRUG BENEFITS MANAGER

docs.abstract: Aetna, seeking to stem rising prescription drug costs, says it will end its mail-order contract with pharmaceutical benefits manager Express Scripts and conduct business itself; Aetna reports third-quarter earnings of $53 million, up from $32 million year ago (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Cigna Corporation's chief financial officer, James G. Stewart, will retire in December after 36 years at the company, a leading health insurer. Mr. Stewart, 60, will be succeeded by Michael W. Bell, 39, an 18-year employee of the company, Cigna said. Gregory Wolf, 46, will succeed Mr. Bell as president of Cigna Group Insurance, its group disability, life and accident insurance unit.

headline.main: HEALTH INSURER'S CHIEF FINANCIAL OFFICER TO RETIRE

docs.lead_paragraph: Red brick buildings, neatly trimmed lawns and river birch trees dot the campus of Gardner-Webb University in the heart of this small, Bible Belt town. Gardner-Webb was founded as a Baptist college and is known historically for producing teachers and preachers. Alcohol is banned, the student honor code is posted in every classroom and no building eclipses the steeple of Dover Chapel. It is hard to imagine a setting less likely to produce a scandal over manipulating a top basketball player's grade point average. But Christian values, academic integrity and college sports collided at Gardner-Webb over the last month, after the university president admitted he had ordered that the university's rules be ignored in the calculation of a star player's G.P.A. to keep the player eligible.
docs.abstract: Gardner-Webb University, Christian school with Division I basketball program, falls under intense scrutiny after university president Christohper White is forced to resign for changing athlete's failing grade to keep him eligible to play; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Health costs are spiraling into another year of double-digit increases. Patients, employers and government health programs are feeling the financial pain. But where is the money going? And why do health costs continue to rise when in so many other parts of the economy -- from cars to clothes to computers -- prices are falling and profit margins are being squeezed?

headline.main: The Healthier Side Of Health Care

docs.abstract: Big winners in thriving health-care industry are hospitals, particularly those that have assembled networks that dominate local markets, makers of ingenious medical devices and nurses, who are getting big raises and better working conditions; strongest managed care companies are reporting sharply higher profits, as premiums rise even faster than do underlying costs; growth of spending on drugs is slowing, after decade-long bonanza of profits for drug companies; graphs; photos (M)

keywords.value: HEALTH MAINTENANCE ORGANIZATIONS AND MANAGED CARE

docs.lead_paragraph: Oxford Health Plans, one of the New York area's biggest health insurers, said third-quarter net income fell on costs from class-action lawsuits that were filed after company shares plunged in 1997. Oxford said it expected net income of about 26 cents a share, compared with 85 cents in the period last year. Oxford will post complete third-quarter results on Oct. 29, which will include a pretax charge of $151.3 million, or 98 cents a share, related to the lawsuits. Excluding the legal costs, Oxford, based in Trumbull, Conn., would have had a profit of $1.24 a share in the most recent quarter, the company said.

headline.main: COSTS FROM LAWSUITS HURT INCOME AT OXFORD HEALTH
